A 3-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with acute kidney injury and a
history of bloody diarrhea. Her initial laboratory studies show a blood urea nitrogen of 98
mg/dL (34.9 mmol/L), creatinine of 5.4 mg/dL (477 µmol/L), sodium of 140 mEq/L (140
mmol/L), potassium of 7.8 mEq/L (7.8 mmol/L), chloride of 98 mEq/L (98 mmol/L), and
bicarbonate is 12 mEq/L. The serum calcium is 8.2 mg/dL (2.05 mmol/L) and
phosphorus is 7.9 mg/dL (2.55 mmol/L). The hemoglobin is 7.2 g/dL (72 g/L) and the
platelet count is 54 ×103/µL (54 x 109/L). The history, physical examination, and
laboratory results are consistent with hemolytic uremic syndrome.
Of the following, the most life threatening clinical manifestation of hyperkalemia is
explanation:
E. ventricular fibrillation
Hyperkalemia impairs cardiovascular, neuromuscular, renal, endocrine, and metabolic
dysfunction. The most life-threatening complication of hyperkalemia is cardiac
arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation and asystole. Hyperkalemia causes the
cardiac membrane potential to be unsteady by altering the resting membrane potential.
An unsteady cardiac membrane potential can result in cardiac arrhythmias, including
peaked T-waves, widening of the QRS complex, loss of P waves, asystole, and
ventricular fibrillation. These findings are based not only on the level of extracellular
potassium, but also on how quickly the change in potassium level has occurred over
time. Electrocardiographic changes that generally occur at a concentration greater than
7 mEq/L (7 mmol/L) in children with chronic hyperkalemia may be seen at lower levels
in children with an acute rapid rise in serum potassium, resulting in a swift decrease in
the transmembrane potassium gradient.
In patients with acidosis, the excess hydrogen ions are buffered in the intracellular
compartment and electroneutrality is maintained by movement of the intracellular
potassium into the extracellular space.
Muscle weakness is usually ascending, beginning in the legs and progressing to the
trunk and arms, which can progress to flaccid paralysis.
Emergent treatment of hyperkalemia includes nebulized albuterol, intravenous calcium
to stabilize membrane potential, intravenous sodium bicarbonate to drive potassium
intracellularly, and glucose and insulin to also drive potassium into cells. Sodium
polystyrene sulfonate and the initiation of dialysis therapy are used to remove potassium
from the body.
There are many causes of hyperkalemia including acute kidney injury, spurious
hyperkalemia, drug-induced hyperkalemia, type 4 renal tubular acidosis, increased
tissue catabolism as occurs in tumor lysis syndrome, hemolysis, and necrotic tissue, as
well as other causes.
While hyperkalemia may be the result of reduced renin (and aldosterone) secretion,
once developed, hyperkalemia leads to an increase in renin secretion, a compensatory

mechanism designed to improve renal potassium secretion. Incidentally, the increase in
renin also results in renal vessel vasodilation and reduced or unchanged normal systemic
vascular resistance. Hyperkalemia does not cause increased blood pressure. While
hyperkalemia may lead to skeletal muscle weakness (eg, flaccid paralysis) and smooth
muscle dysfunction (eg, paralytic ileus), the most serious outcomes of hyperkalemia are
cardiac conduction disturbance and arrhythmias.
PREP Pearls
 Cardiac arrhythmias are the most life threatening complication of hyperkalemia
 There are multiple causes of hyperkalemia in children
 Severe hyperkalemia required urgent treatment
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the clinical manifestations of hyperkalemia
Suggested Readings
 Andreoli SP. Acute renal failure: clinical evaluation and management. In: Avner
ED, Harmon WE, Niaudet P, Yoshikawa N, ed. Pediatric Nephrology. Baltimore, MD:
Springer; 2009:1233-1254.
 Bainchetti MG, Bettinelli A. Differential diagnosis and management of fluid,
electrolyte, and acid-base disorders. In: Geary DF, Schaefer F, ed. Comprehensive
Pediatric Nephrology. Philadelphia, PA: Mosby Elsevier; 2008:395-431.

You are evaluating a 15-year-old adolescent in your office for new onset hypertension.
She is overweight but not obese and has stage 1 hypertension. While taking her history,
you inquire about her birth history. When you ask about her birth weight, her mother
asks you why this piece of information is important.
Of the following, the MOST appropriate response to her is
options: being large for gestational age is an independent risk factor for hypertension in adolescence and beyond
greater birth weight is an early risk factor for the development of cardiovascular disease risk factors
hypertension is more common in children with a low birth weight because of chronic inflammation
lower birth weight is associated with hypertension caused by a lower nephron endowment
secondary hypertension is more likely than primary hypertension among adolescents with a low birth weight
explanation:
D. lower birth weight is associated with hypertension caused by a lower nephron
endowment
Obtaining a detailed birth history is an important part of your initial evaluation of any
pediatric patient presenting with a new diagnosis of hypertension. Birth weight provides
information and can initiate dialogue regarding potential prenatal and early postnatal
risk factors, maternal health and nutrition, premature delivery, and the early neonatal
course, including any need for a neonatal intensive care unit stay. In addition, low birth
weight is a risk for masked hypertension.
Low birth weight is often a result of prematurity or suboptimal fetal growth. Both can
lead to impaired or incomplete renal development, resulting in diminished nephron
endowment. Nephrogenesis is not complete until approximately week 34 to 36 of
gestation, therefore neonates born earlier than that time period may not develop their
full complement of nephrons. While nephrogenesis can occur postnatally, it is often
suboptimal, does not progress much further than 40 days after birth, and is often
compromised by further renal insults related to the care of premature infants (eg,
sepsis, hypotension, administration of nephrotoxic agents such as furosemide and
gentamicin). As a result, premature infants are at risk for lower functional renal mass
than those born full term, placing them at risk for hypertension.
Neonates born full term but small for gestational age are also at increased risk for the
development of hypertension. Both animal and human studies have demonstrated
higher blood pressures among those born with low birth weight when compared to those
not born small. This risk is also shown to increase with increasing age: for each 1 kg
increase in birth weight, blood pressure is lower by 1 to 3 mm Hg in adolescence, and
lower by 5.2 mm Hg among individuals 64 to 71 years of age. The etiology of this
association is also felt to be related to lower nephron mass, termed "congenital
oligonephropathy,” among low birth weight individuals related to the intrauterine
environment and impaired renal development. In addition, low birth weight neonates
also often experience “catch-up growth” that places increased metabolic demands on the
kidneys. This accelerated postnatal growth can lead to further nephron loss.
Congenital oligonephropathy leads to hypertension via hyperfiltration of the remaining
nephrons and eventual glomerulosclerosis over time, with further nephron dropout

similar to what is seen in renal disease. This compensatory renal hypertrophy among
individuals born with a low birth weight and its association with hypertension was nicely
demonstrated in 2 studies of white adults. Individuals with low birth weight had almost
25% lower nephron endowment, with each individual glomerulus larger than expected
when compared to individuals who did not have a low birth weight. When the overall
glomerular tuft volume (number of glomeruli x average glomerular volume) was
compared, there was no difference between groups based on birth weight. This
preserved glomerular tuft volume despite lower nephron endowment was also
demonstrated when the same individuals were dichotomized based on their hypertensive
status; hypertensive individuals had fewer, larger glomeruli with overall unchanged total
glomerular tuft volume compared to normotensive individuals.
Interestingly, neither the association of hypertension with congenital oligonephropathy
nor with low birth weight is as clearly evident among African Americans. In contrast to
the previously mentioned studies done in white adults, several studies have shown no
difference in glomerular number or birth weight between hypertensive and normotensive
African Americans.
While high birth weight (> 10 lbs) is known to be associated with the development of
obesity in adulthood, it is not an independent risk factor for the development of
hypertension. In fact, a high nephron number protects against the development of salt-
induced chronic hypertension. Further, it is lower birth weight neonates, not greater
birth weight neonates, that are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease risk factors
later in life such as diabetes, insulin resistance, and endothelial dysfunction. This
increased risk is thought to be caused by accelerated postnatal weight gain. Increased
early weight gain velocity is also independently associated with greater blood pressure
and hypertension later in life. While neonates with low birth weight may experience
greater neonatal stress and be exposed to more inflammatory processes, this is not
considered part of the pathogenesis of later hypertension.
Finally, low birth weight adolescents newly diagnosed with hypertension are more likely
to have primary, not secondary, hypertension.
Additional Readings

PREP Pearls
 Low birth weight, either caused by prematurity or suboptimal fetal growth, is
associated with elevated blood pressure and primary hypertension. This is because
of impaired or incomplete renal development, resulting in diminished nephron
endowment, compensatory hypertrophy, and hyperfiltration, leading ultimately to
glomerulosclerosis
 Accelerated postnatal growth is another risk factor for the later development of
hypertension among children born with a low birth weight
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the possible role of prematurity and low birth weight in blood pressure
throughout childhood
Suggested Readings
 Curhan GC, Chertow GM, Willett WC, et al. Birth weight and adult hypertension
and obesity in women. Circulation. 1996;94(6):1310-1315. DOI:
10.1161/01.CIR.94.6.1310
 Curhan GC, Willett WC, Rimm EB, Spiegelman D, Ascherio AL, Stampfer MJ. Birth
weight and adult hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and obesity in US men. Circulation.
1996;94(12):3246-3250. DOI: 10.1161/01.CIR.94.12.3246

You are seeing a previously healthy 4-year-old girl who was brought to the emergency
room 6 hours ago with vomiting, diarrhea, and diminished urine output. The triage nurse
recorded a heart rate of 140 beats/min, blood pressure of 75/40 mm Hg, and a
prolonged capillary refill time. The patient has received 3 boluses of intravenous normal
saline (20 mL/kg each), but has remained anuric. Examination after resuscitation
reveals an alert child who is still nauseous and having diarrheal stools, with a heart rate
of 80 beats/min, blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg, and mild peripheral edema. Initial
laboratory test results are now available and show a blood urea nitrogen of 40 mg/dL
(14.3 mmol/L) and serum creatinine of 1.8 mg/dL (159 µmol/L).
Of the following, the BEST next step in the management of this patient is
options: an additional intravenous fluid bolus of 20 mL/kg normal saline
intravenous D5 one-half normal saline with 20 mEq/L of potassium at twice maintenance rate
intravenous D5 one-fourth normal saline at a rate of 300 mL/m2 per day plus replace ongoing losses
stop all intravenous fluids and await urine output
explanation:
C. intravenous D5 one-fourth normal saline at a rate of 300 mL/m2 per day plus replace
ongoing losses
The patient in this vignette presented with oliguria and acute dehydration from a
gastrointestinal illness. Initial evaluation revealed 10% to 15% dehydration, and initial
appropriate therapy with fluid boluses of 20 mL/kg normal saline was administered.
Adequacy of fluid therapy is demonstrated by the normalization of heart rate and blood
pressure. However, she has remained anuric and has now developed worrisome
peripheral edema. Laboratory evaluation meets the diagnostic criteria for acute kidney
injury (AKI). Based on the increase in serum creatinine to greater than 3 times the
expected normal value for her age, as well as the persistent anuria, she currently has
AKI stage 3 based on Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) staging. The
most appropriate management at this time is to provide intravenous D5 one-fourth
normal saline (without potassium) at a rate of 300 mL/m2 per day (to account for
insensible water losses) and additionally replace any ongoing losses from diarrhea or
vomiting.
Gastrointestinal illnesses are the commonest cause of dehydration and pre-renal AKI
worldwide. In many cases, patients present with oliguria and an increase in blood urea
nitrogen (BUN) and serum creatinine, with a history and physical findings consistent
with dehydration and a pre-renal etiology. In such cases, a fluid challenge may be
diagnostic as well as therapeutic. Typically, fluid challenges in children consist of normal
saline in the dose of 10 to 20 mL/kg, repeated once or twice until urine output improves.
Adequacy of fluid therapy is best demonstrated by the normalization of vital signs and
physical examination, re-establishment of urine flow (and a subsequent reduction in BUN
and serum creatinine), all of which would also confirm a pre-renal etiology. Thus, any
child with a clinical history and physical examination consistent with hypovolemia
requires immediate intravenous fluid therapy in an attempt to restore renal function and
prevent the progression of pre-renal AKI to intrinsic AKI. Commonly used fluid for
resuscitation is normal saline (20 mL/kg given over 30 min, repeated twice as needed).
Increasing evidence suggests that isotonic crystalloids such as normal saline should be
used instead of colloids for initial expansion of intravascular volume in patients at risk
for AKI or with AKI.

The majority of children with dehydration will respond to 2 to 3 intravenous boluses of
normal saline and can then be switched to standard regimens that allow for complete
rehydration to occur in the subsequent 24 hours. These regimens typically employ
intravenous D5 one-half normal saline with 20 mEq/L of potassium at twice the
maintenance rate. However, the persistence of anuria and development of fluid overload
(as exemplified by the vignette), or an absence of improvement in BUN and serum
creatinine, would indicate the diagnosis of intrinsic AKI and would call for an urgent
change in medical management. When urine output does not improve after restoration
of intravascular volume, more invasive monitoring (including bladder catheterization,
imaging of the kidney and urinary tract, and central venous pressure monitoring in
select cases) may be required to guide further therapy. The clinician must also pay
careful attention to ongoing fluid losses (insensible water loss of approximately 300 to
500 mL/m2 per day, in addition to replacement of urine and gastrointestinal losses) and
gains (fluids, medications, and nutrition administered). Insensible water losses are
higher in febrile children and lower in ventilated children with decreased respiratory
losses. Insensible water losses are best replaced with D5 one-fourth normal saline, and
potassium should be avoided until after urine output has been convincingly
demonstrated.
In patients with fluid overload, the achievement of negative balance may require
replacement of less than the total ongoing losses. Early renal replacement therapy
should be considered for critically ill children with intrinsic AKI and greater than 10% to
20% fluid overload who are not expected to recover kidney function expeditiously.
The other responses provided in the vignette are incorrect. Additional boluses of normal
saline are contraindicated in anuric children with physical signs of fluid overload, due to
the risk of pulmonary edema. Intravenous potassium is contraindicated in anuric
patients. Stopping all intravenous fluids in this child with ongoing diarrheal losses carries
the risk of recurrence of dehydration and worsening AKI. In children with hypotension
not responsive to volume repletion alone, preservation of blood pressure and renal
perfusion with appropriate inotropic agents may be considered to prevent AKI. However,
in children who are volume replete with normalization of blood pressure (as in this
vignette), the use of inotropic agents such as “renal dose” dopamine is not indicated.
The use of low “renal dose” of the inotropic agent dopamine (0.5 to 3 mg/kg/min) is
common in the critical care setting because of its renal vasodilatory and natriuretic

effects. However, prospective randomized studies of adult patients at risk for AKI have
not shown a beneficial renoprotective effect of “renal dose” dopamine. Furthermore,
there are risks associated with even “renal dose” dopamine, including tachycardia,
arrhythmias, myocardial ischemia, and intestinal ischemia. Therefore, the routine use of
dopamine for prevention or treatment of AKI is not recommended.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Evaluate the clinical course and adequacy of fluid therapy for an oliguric patient
Suggested Readings
 Devarajan P. Pediatric acute kidney injury: different from acute renal failure, but
how and why. Curr Pediatr Rep. 2013;1(1):34-40. DOI: 10.1007/s40124-012-0003-3
 Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) Acute Kidney Injury Work
Group. KDIGO clinical practice guideline for acute kidney injury. Kidney Int.
2012;2(Suppl):1–138. Available at:
www.kdigo.org/clinical_practice_guidelines/pdf/KDIGO%20AKI%20Guideline.pdf

A 9-year-old boy is referred to you with asymptomatic microscopic hematuria. His past
medical history and physical examination are unremarkable. Since he was adopted, the
family history is unknown. Urinalysis is normal except for 12 red blood cells/high power
field. You order a random urine test for calcium-to-creatinine ratio and the result is 0.45
mg/mg. Further investigations reveal a 24 hour urine calcium excretion of 5.8
mg/kg/day, serum calcium of 9.6 mg/dL (2.40 mmol/L), phosphate of 4.6 mg/dL (1.49
mmol/L), parathyroid hormone of 21 pg/mL (21 ng/L), and a 1,25 vitamin D of 121
3
pg/mL (315 pmol/L).
Of the following, the MOST likely cause for hypercalciuria in this patient is
explanation:
D. renal hypercalciuria
In 1978, Moore et al showed that the prevalence of hypercalciuria in children is about
3% to 6%. The cutoff for normal calcium excretion varies by age. While a
calcium/creatinine ratio of less than 0.2 mg/mg is considered normal in older children
and adolescents, higher ratios are considered normal in neonates and infants. Generally,
hypercalciuria in children is defined as urine calcium excretion exceeding 4 mg/kg/day.
The random urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio can be used to screen for hypercalciuria,
while the timed collection, if feasible to perform, confirms the diagnosis.
While the pathogenesis of hypercalciuria was traditionally thought to be caused by either
increased intestinal calcium absorption or increased renal calcium excretion, the process
is far more complex. The approach to patients with hypercalciuria therefore requires
understanding about the differentiation of types of hypercalciuria. Indeed, as elegantly
described by Srivastava and Schwaderer and others, understanding the pathogenesis of
hypercalciuria requires knowledge about the roles of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract,
bone, kidneys, and several hormones in calcium homeostasis.
Idiopathic hypercalciuria may result from one (or combinations of) of several processes:
1) Type I absorptive hypercalciuria: This is caused by increased calcium absorption in
the GI tract. Patients with this type feature normal serum calcium and normal or low
parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. Examples include congenital sucrase-isomaltase
deficiency, glucose-galactose malabsorption, Down syndrome, Williams-Beuren
syndrome, and blue diaper syndrome.
2) Type II absorptive hypercalciuria: This rare entity is caused by elevated 1,25-
dihydroxyvitamin D-stimulated calcium absorption. These patients may not develop
elevated urinary calcium levels if kept on a low calcium diet.
3) Type III absorptive hypercalciuria: Patients with this subtype have decreased renal
reabsorption of phosphorus (renal phosphate leak), leading to hypophosphatemia. This
stimulates the conversion of 25 vitamin D to 1,25 vitamin D, resulting in increased
intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate. The end result is hypercalciuria. The
serum calcium and PTH levels are usually normal. The cause is usually elusive.
4) Renal hypercalciuria: This type reveals decreased renal reabsorption of calcium.

Initially, the serum calcium level is low, stimulating high PTH and vitamin D levels. This
3
induces increased GI absorption of calcium and hypercalciuria. Examples include
idiopathic hypercalciuria, Dent disease, hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with
hypercalciuria, Wilson disease, familial hypomagnesemia with hypercalciuria and
nephrocalcinosis, Liddle syndrome, and Lowe syndrome.
5) Resorptive hypercalciuria: This is due to enhanced bone resorption and is generally
caused by hyperparathyroidism. Affected patients develop hypercalcemia, elevated
vitamin D levels, and hypercalciuria. Examples include McCune-Albright syndrome,
3
multiple endocrine neoplasia 1 syndrome, Jansen disease, and infantile
hypophosphatasia.
In most children with idiopathic hypercalciuria with normal serum calcium, no further
investigations other than 24 hour urine collection may be needed for diagnosis. In
selected cases, laboratory tests are needed for further evaluation of hypercalciuria and
differentiating the subtypes listed; symptomatic patients (ie, with suspected
nephrolithiasis) may also require renal imaging studies. In asymptomatic children,
laboratory evaluation could include a detailed but focused and logical metabolic screen.
This should be done while the patient is on a regular diet. The initial blood tests should
include serum calcium, creatinine, and phosphate studies, along with PTH and vitamin D
levels. If the history, examination, and initial laboratory tests do not provide definite
clues to the etiology of hypercalciuria, a calcium-loading test may be performed for
further evaluation. In patients with absorptive (GI) hypercalciuria, urine samples will
show a significant increase in urine calcium concentration. In contrast, calcium loading
does not result in an increase in urine calcium concentration in patients with renal
hypercalciuria.
The boy in the vignette has normal serum calcium and phosphate levels, along with a
low PTH level and elevated 1,25 vitamin D level. Patients with Dent disease have renal
3
hypercalciuria and also feature mild proteinuria and excessive amino acid excretion. The
diagnosis can be established by genetic testing of the patient or of the affected parent.
Since Dent disease is inherited in a X-linked pattern, it almost exclusively affects males.
The lack of available information about this boy’s family history complicates the
evaluation. While patients with type I absorptive hypercalciuria may have normal serum
calcium and phosphate levels, with low PTH levels, they often have a clinical history (eg,
syndrome) featuring enhanced GI calcium absorption. Type II is rare, and the patient

would have an elevated, not suppressed, 1,25 vitamin D level. Patients with type III
3
have hypophosphatemia, while those with the resorptive type feature hypercalcemia and
elevated 1,25 vitamin D .
3
As mentioned, the serum calcium level alone can provide valuable clues to the etiology
of hypercalciuria. The Table shows the various causes of hypercalciuria, depending on
the serum calcium level.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the causes of hypercalciuria with a normal serum calcium and with a high
serum calcium
Suggested Readings
 Polito C, La Manna A, Cioce F, Villani J, Nappi B, Di Toro R. Clinical presentation
and natural course of idiopathic hypercalciuria in children. Pediatr Nephrol. 2000;15(3-
4):211–214.
 Spivacow FR, Negri AL, del Valle EE, Calviño I, Fradinger E, Zanchetta JR.
Metabolic risk factors in children with kidney stone disease. Pediatr Nephrol.
2008;23(7):1129–1133. DOI: 10.1007/s00467-008-0769-2
 Srivastava T, Schwaderer A. Diagnosis and management of hypercalciuria in
children. Curr Opin Pediatr. 2009;21(2):214-219. DOI:
10.1097/MOP.0b013e3283223db7

You are evaluating a 3-year-old boy who received a living donor renal transplant 1 day
ago. He had end stage renal disease caused by diffuse mesangial sclerosis. The graft is
functioning well, but the serum sodium concentration is slowly decreasing and is
currently 133 mEq/L (133 mmol/L). You evaluate his overall fluid status and do not
believe that he is fluid overloaded, as evidenced by a central venous pressure of 5 cm
H O, blood pressure of 94/62 mm Hg, and a heart rate of 110 beats/min. You review his
2
medications, which include basiliximab, cyclosporine, corticosteroids, cefazolin, and
dopamine. He is receiving normal saline intravenously. A random urine sodium level is
78 mEq/L (78 mmol/L). Urinalysis is normal with a specific gravity of 1.014.
Of the following, the MOST likely cause of hyponatremia in conjunction with high urine
sodium in this child is
explanation:
C. dopamine infusion
Substances that stimulate the renal sodium-potassium ATPase (Na-K-ATPase) contribute
to reduced retention of Na, while substances that inhibit the ATPase contribute to
reduced excretion of Na. The catecholamines dopamine and norepinephrine play a
prominent role in the renal regulation of sodium homeostasis and blood pressure. Both
substances interact with the renal tubular sodium-potassium ATPase (Na-K-ATPase) and
thereby play a role in renal sodium regulation.
Dopamine inhibits the ATPase. As a result, dopamine increases sodium excretion and,
under certain circumstances, may contribute to the development of hyponatremia. In
addition, dopamine may further exacerbate hyponatremia by stimulating antidiuretic
hormone (ADH) secretion; this induces sodium excretion, although the role that this
mechanism plays in overall sodium balance is unclear. Indeed, studies in animals and
humans display that dopaminergic agents induce hyponatremia. Dopamine and
norepinephrine mediate their effect on sodium transport via the dopamine-specific
protein phosphatase-1 inhibitor, DARPP-32, and the norepinephrine-activated protein
phosphatase-2B, calcineurin, respectively. These effects are more pronounced during
renal development.
Dopamine infusion is the most likely reason for the development of hyponatremia in the
child in the vignette, via inhibition of the renal Na-K-ATPase. While hyponatremia may
be caused or exacerbated by alterations in fluid balance (eg, hyponatremic dehydration,
retention of water), this child’s vital signs suggest relative euvolemia. While underlying
renal disease may result in renal sodium wasting, this child had a glomerular disease
and did not have the typical histology (eg, renal dysplasia) expected to result in excess
sodium losses. Although dopamine has been suspected to induce ADH secretion, and, as
a result, natriuresis, this mechanism is not confirmed. Regardless, this child’s urine
specific gravity is not consistent with increased ADH activity. Administration of isotonic
intravenous fluid should not cause hyponatremia.
Basiliximab has not been shown to significantly and consistently affect sodium transport,
while corticosteroids stimulate sodium retention. It should be noted that among the
other immunosuppressive agents used in transplant, there is evidence that cyclosporine

and tacrolimus inhibit the Na-K-ATPase, possibly contributing to hyperkalemia. In some
series, tacrolimus has been associated with the development of hyponatremia.
Dopamine is formed in the proximal tubule cells as a result of uptake of filtered L-DOPA,
the latter of which is decarboxylated to dopamine. Dopamine regulates sodium balance
by various mechanisms, including inhibition of proximal tubular sodium reabsorption.
This effect is unrelated to the effect of dopamine as a vasodilator. Dopamine receptors
are essential for its uptake. There are various receptor groups, the most essential being
the D1-like receptors. The D1 receptors are coupled to G proteins. For example, infusion
of a D1-like receptor antagonist (SCH-23390) in animals reveals a significant role for
dopamine in basal sodium excretion. Dopamine inhibits the Na-K-ATPase in the proximal
tubule, thick ascending limb of Henle, distal tubule, and cortical collecting duct. While
D1-like receptors inhibit the ATPase, D2-like receptors generally stimulate the Na-K-
ATPase.
The catecholamines norepinephrine and epinephrine are released from the sympathetic
nerves and the adrenal medulla. The effect of norepinephrine on sodium reabsorption is
opposite to that of dopamine. Norepinephrine activates the Na-K-ATPase, thereby
stimulating Na reabsorption. Studies show that norepinephrine has no impact on the
sodium-hydrogen exchanger or other sodium-dependent (eg, sodium-phosphate
cotransport) mechanisms. While norepinephrine increases sodium retention, it increases
blood pressure. In response to volume depletion, norepinephrine, similar to angiotensin
II, raises the blood pressure while concomitantly stimulating sodium reabsorption via
direct stimulation of proximal and loop of Henle sodium reabsorption, altered peritubular
capillary hemodynamics, and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system by
the ß1-adrenergic receptors. Compared to norepinephrine, epinephrine has a minimal
effect on renal sodium balance.
Catecholamines also regulate renal blood flow and function. Acute increases in renal
perfusion pressure result in a direct increase in urinary sodium excretion via tubular
reabsorption. Indeed, adrenergic innervation has been identified in the renal vasculature
and in the proximal tubule, loop of Henle, and distal tubule. Renal sympathetic activity
tends to be increased in states of effective circulating volume depletion. Norepinephrine
is the most potent vasoconstrictor among the catecholamines and it reduces renal blood
flow in an effort to maintain perfusion to the brain and heart. Dopamine is a renal

vasodilator at low concentrations, thereby lowering renal vascular resistance. Overall,
enhanced sympathetic activity increases sodium reabsorption, an effect that may
contribute to the compensatory renal sodium retention seen with volume depletion. This
occurs via direct effects on the Na-K-ATPases and via increased renin release and renal
vascular resistance, together shifting the pressure-natriuresis curve to the right.
During development, the ability of renal nerve stimulation and catecholamine release to
increase renal vascular resistance and reduce renal blood flow is not as robust as it is in
older subjects. During the antenatal period, renal nerve stimulation generally induces
sodium retention. The concentration of dopamine is higher in the fetal rat than the adult
rat, thereby counterbalancing the retention of sodium exhibited by other
catecholamines.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the role of renal nerves and circulating catecholamines circulating
catecholamines in influencing sodium reabsorption during development
Suggested Readings
 Abdulnour-Nakhoul S, Khuri RN, Nakhoul NL. Effect of norepinephrine on cellular
sodium transport in Ambystoma kidney proximal tubule. Am J Physiol. 1994;267(5 Pt
2):F725-F736.
 Carey RM. Renal dopamine system: paracrine regulator of sodium homeostasis
and blood pressure. Hypertension. 2001;38:297-302. DOI: 10.1161/hy0901.096422

A 13-year-old adolescent comes to your office with her parents for a second opinion.
She was seen by another nephrologist 6 weeks ago for hypertension. On review of
systems, he noted a malar rash. She was found to have 3+ blood and 3+ protein on
urinalysis with a serum albumin of 3.2 g/dL (32 g/L) and serum creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL
(80 µmol/L). At that time, her serum complement C3 level was 65 mg/dL and
complement C4 level was 8 mg/dL. The serum antinuclear antibody was positive at
1:640, while the anti-double stranded DNA level was 21 units/mL.
Her blood pressure is currently 150/90 mm Hg (manual- repeated measurements). On
examination, she has a faint malar rash, single mouth ulcer, and slight pedal edema.
Urinalysis shows 3+ blood and 3+ protein, with 2 to 3 red blood cell casts per high
powered field.
The outside nephrologist was concerned that she has lupus nephritis and recommended
a renal biopsy, and management of hypertension with initiation of a calcium channel
blocker and a low salt diet. The family has refused vaccinations in the past. She has not
yet started therapy with the antihypertensive, but has reduced sodium intake. The
family does not want a biopsy performed and would prefer to manage her disease with
diet and supplements.
Assuming she has lupus nephritis (World Health Organization class III or IV), the MOST
accurate statement regarding this patient’s disease is
options: progression to end stage kidney disease in treated childhood lupus nephritis most commonly occurs in the first decade of disease
should she go to end stage kidney disease and receive a kidney transplant, her prognosis is significantly worse than other transplant patients
whole exome sequencing will likely reveal a single gene defect causing her lupus nephritis
with modern treatment, her risk of progression to end stage renal disease is less than 3%
untreated, her predicted survival to 18 years of age is less than 50%
explanation:
E. untreated, her predicted survival to 18 years of age is less than 50%
This patient presents a difficult dilemma. The severity and significance of diseases that
are now mostly controllable or preventable is not appreciated by some families. To
understand the often malignant catastrophic course of untreated childhood lupus
nephritis, one must go back to the literature.
In 1 published study describing 150 patients with systemic lupus (approximately one-
third of whom had pediatric systemic lupus) in the early 1970s, patient survival before
the use of cyclophosphamide or rituximab was approximately 75% at 5 years after onset
of disease. Studies done from the early 1950s to mid-1960s reported 5-year survival
rates around 50%. For those with lupus nephritis in those studies, the 5-year patient
survival rate with diffuse proliferative or membranous lesion was approximately 30%,
and for those with focal proliferative lupus, patient survival was around 70%. Thus, the
natural history of untreated systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is dismal.
The presentation of childhood lupus rarely occurs before 5 years of age (< 5%) and
most patients (about 60%) present after 10 years of age. Compared to adults, children
have a more severe presentation with a higher risk of hemolytic anemia, lupus nephritis,
malar rash, and systemic features such as weight loss, fever, and fatigue. Lupus
nephritis occurs in over 50% of patients with systemic lupus in most childhood series.
Despite modern therapy, up to 10% of children with severe forms of lupus nephritis may
progress to end stage kidney disease (ESKD) within 5 years of onset of lupus nephritis.
However, after renal transplantation, the majority of children with a history of ESKD due
to lupus nephritis achieve outcomes similar to those with other causes of ESKD. These
patients do have an elevated risk of death (1.8-fold) possibly related to other
comorbidities.
The long term outcome of childhood onset lupus in adulthood has been examined in a
large cohort of 662 childhood systemic lupus patients. The patients in the study were
diagnosed after 1983 and were 81% female, with an average follow-up of 10.7 years.
Forty-four percent of the patients had biopsy-proven lupus nephritis. During the
observation period, 7% developed ESKD. The mean age of ESKD onset was 30 years of
age, and ESKD occurred about 18 years after disease onset. Other reported

complications of lupus included hip, knee, and ankle replacements (less than 4%),
malignancy (2%), and cerebral vascular accidents (6%). Thus, the long term, treated
natural history of systemic lupus and lupus nephritis in the modern era is still
concerning.
The prevalence and demographics of SLE in children has been studied. In a Medicaid-
enrolled population, the prevalence is approximately 10 per 100,000 children. In that
study, SLE was over 5 times more common in girls than boys and over one-third had
lupus nephritis. In addition, there was a higher prevalence of both lupus and lupus
nephritis among nonwhite children; per 100,000 Medicaid-enrolled children a prevalence
of 23.79 in patients of Asian ancestory, 14.08 in African Americans, 11.51 in Hispanics,
13.38 in Native Americans and 4.86 among Whites was found. Geographically, the rates
of SLE and lupus nephritis are lower in the Midwest compared to other regions of the
United States, which has been ascribed in part to differences in regional ethnic
composition.
The comparative risk for SLE nephritis in children based on ancestry or ethnicity has not
been reported. In North American adults, the risk for SLE is highest for those with West-
African and African-Caribbean descent. There is also evidence for an increased risk for
SLE among individuals with Native American, Polynesian, Asian Indian, Chinese, and
certain Hispanic (Mestizo) backgrounds, with a reduced risk among individuals with
European ancestry.
Genetics has a strong role in SLE susceptibility with a concordance rate in monozygotic
twins of over 25%, and, in some series, over 50%. Dizygotic twins have only a 2% to
5% concordance rate. Despite the extensive efforts to assess the genetic risks for SLE
with genome-wide association studies, it appears that much of the genetic susceptibility
to SLE is caused by numerous variants that are common in the population and
contribute a small or modest degree to disease susceptibility. For example, while various
genetic factors such as the genes IRF5, STAT4, and TRAF1-C5 seem to increase the
susceptibility to developing SLE, they have not been shown to increase the risk for lupus
nephritis.
Overall, the propensity for renal involvement is highest in adults of sub-Saharan African
ancestry. Recently, the risk for ESKD in African Americans with lupus nephritis was

found to be strongly associated with the APOL1 risk alleles, with an adjusted odds ratio
of 2.7 for those carrying risk alleles. Some of this excess risk was reduced after
adjustment for hypertension and diabetes.
Additional Readings
PREP Pearls
 Untreated lupus nephritis is deadly
 Multiple genes are associated with lupus susceptibility
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the natural history and epidemiology of systemic lupus erythematosus
Suggested Readings
 Aggarwal A, Srivastava P. Childhood onset systemic lupus erythematosus: how is
it different from adult SLE. Int J Rheum Dis. 2014. DOI: 10.1111/1756-185X.12419
 Borchers AT, Naguwa SM, Shoenfeld Y, Gershwin ME. The geoepidemiology of
systemic lupus erythematosus. Autoimmun Rev. 2010;9(5):A277-A287. DOI:
10.1016/j.autrev.2009.12.008

You are consulted on a 3-day-old baby who is admitted with fever, excessive crying,
episodes of vomiting, and ascites. The abdominal ultrasonography showed ascites and
minimal pelvicaliectasis on both sides with normal size kidneys and a normal bladder. An
ascitic tap was performed and the results are shown:
· Protein: 3.1 g/dL (31 g/L)
· Lactate dehydrogenase: 150 U/L (2.5 µkat/L)
· pH: 7.10
· Cholesterol: 56 mg/dL (1.45 mmol/L)
· Specific gravity: 1.025
· Glucose: 48 mg/dL (2.7 mmol/L)
· White blood cells per mm³: 200
Of the following, the MOST likely etiology for ascites in this neonate is
explanation:
D. peritonitis
Ascites is defined as the accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, causing
abdominal swelling. Most ascitic fluid in adults accumulates as a result of a disease
process affecting the hepatic or gastrointestinal systems, but other systems that may be
involved in the pathogenesis include the urinary tract.
A useful and instructive way to assess the pathogenesis of ascites is to consider if the
fluid represents a transudate (low protein [< 2.5 g/dL], low lactate dehydrogenase
[LDH], high pH [at least 7.40], low cholesterol, low specific gravity [< 1.012], normal
glucose, and fewer than 1 white blood cell per 1,000 mm³) versus an exudate (high
protein [> 2.5 g/dL], high LDH, low pH [<7.30], high cholesterol, high specific gravity
[> 1.020], low glucose, and many white blood cells per 1,000 mm³). Finally, measuring
the serum to ascitic fluid albumin gradient (SAAG) may help differentiate a transudate
due to hepatic disease or portal system obstruction from other causes; a high (> 1.1
g/dL) gradient suggests the etiology is in the hepatic and portal system. Observing the
appearance of the fluid may also be informative; peritoneal fluid is usually straw-colored
and clear. The fluid may be yellow in patients with liver disease, milky in patients with
lymphatic obstruction, red-tinged if blood is present, green in the presence of bile, and
cloudy if there are microorganisms.
The peritoneal fluid analysis for the neonate in the vignette is a classic exudate (high
protein, high LDH, low pH, high cholesterol, high specific gravity, low glucose, and many
white blood cells per mm³). Given the paracentesis results, the most likely cause of this
neonate’s ascites is an inflammatory process, such as peritonitis. Congenital
neuroblastoma is a rare cause of ascites in the newborn period. Ascites from liver
disease would yield a transudate, not an exudate. Moreover, the appearance of ascites
from hepatobiliary disease is often delayed for several weeks after birth. It is also
important to note that other causes of a transudate may include cardiac disease or
nephrotic syndrome. Obstruction from lymphatic drainage (chylous ascites) would not
ordinarily yield an exudate.
In older children and adults, transudates are often the result of increased pressure in the
portal vein (due to liver diseases such as cirrhosis), while exudates are generally the

result of an inflammatory or malignant process. In the newborn period, there are many
causes of ascites. In 1 series of 27 cases of neonatal ascites, the causes were: urinary
(7 cases) caused by congenital urinary tract malformations such as posterior urethral
valves and vesicoureteral reflux, gastrointestinal (5 cases) caused by ileal and other
malformations or obstructions, cardiac (3 cases) caused by paroxysmal supraventricular
tachycardia, hepatic (2 cases), and mixed causes (10 cases). In another case series,
Lord et al reviewed 28 fully documented cases of neonatal ascites and found a definite
etiology in 22 cases, among which 18 had obstructive urinary tract lesions, the most
common being posterior urethral valves. Yet, while urinary tract obstruction is a
common cause of neonatal ascites, the likelihood of developing urinary ascites from a
congenital urinary tract malformation is very low, or about 1 in every 100 cases. Other
common causes of neonatal ascites are listed in the Table.

Table. Causes of Neonatal Ascites.
Urinary Tract:
o Posterior urethral valves
o Intraperitoneal bladder
o Vesicoureteral reflux
o Neurogenic bladder/rupture
o Ureteral obstruction/perforation
Gastrointestinal:
o Ruptured liver tumor or hemangioma
o Intestinal lymphangiectasia
o Spontaneous bile duct perforation
o Perforation of the gall bladder
o Stress ulcer
Other:
o Chylous ascites
o Congenital neuroblastoma
o Stress ulcer
o Ruptured adrenal
o Ruptured spleen
o Meconium ileus
o Fetal hydrops
o Heart failure
o Persistent cloaca
o Hernia

Another cause of ascites in the newborn is chylous ascites. In adults, chylous ascites is
commonly caused by lymph obstruction or intra-abdominal malignancy; in the newborn,
it is usually secondary to congenital obstruction of the lymphatic system, including
stenosis of the thoracic duct. Another proposed etiology is poor communication between
the peripheral and central (major) lymphatic systems. The onset of symptoms may be
insidious. If there is chylous ascites at birth, there may be abdominal distension and
respiratory distress with a fluid hernia.
The most common cause of neonatal ascites is the urinary tract, therefore the fluid may
be straw-colored. Identifying the site of leakage from the urinary tract was previously
difficult, but with modern imaging studies, this is now more feasible. Urine may leak
from any site along the urinary tract, therefore careful attention to all sites is prudent.
Once urine leaks into the subcapsular space, it will easily find its way into the peritoneal
cavity. When urinary ascites presents at birth, there is often a history of premature
labor. The birth weight is usually normal, but the abdomen is distended and there may
be respiratory compromise. It is not uncommon, in milder cases of obstruction and leak,
for there to be a delay in presentation of ascites for several weeks.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the different causes of ascites in the newborn period
Suggested Readings
 Aslam M, DeGrazia M, Gregory ML. Diagnostic evaluation of neonatal ascites. Am J
Perinatol. 2007;24(10):603-609. DOI: 10.1055/s-2007-992350
 Griscom NT, Colodny AH, Rosenberg HK, Fliegel CP, Hardy BE. Diagnostic aspects
of neonatal ascites: report of 27 cases. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 1977;128(6):961-969.
Available at: www.ajronline.org/doi/pdf/10.2214/ajr.128.6.961

A 12-year-old German child who has been receiving stable peritoneal dialysis for just
over 1 year is now relocating to the United States with his family. They have been
instructed to expect some changes in their home regimen, as they had been using
double-chamber bags with their cycler machine, which are not available for use at your
center.
In addition to retraining the parents on the different cycler and equipment, the other
potential adverse effects that may also be seen with this change in peritoneal dialysis
solutions is
explanation:
C. inflow pain
Bicarbonate-based peritoneal dialysate (PD) solutions are available in many countries
outside of the United States, but have not yet been approved for use in the United
States. There is a risk for calcium carbonate precipitation, so a double chamber bag is
used that separates the basic and acidic solutions until being used on the cycler
machine. This is unique from the lactate-based solutions that are used in the United
States.
The improved biocompatibility of bicarbonate-based solutions has many reported
benefits over lactate-based solutions including increased ultrafiltration volume, better
preservation of urine output, and reduced inflow pain. Inflow pain is felt to be a direct
consequence of the acidic pH of standard lactate-based solutions, while bicarbonate-
based solutions have a neutral pH and are less likely to cause this adverse effect.
There are a variety of PD solutions available both inside and outside of the United
States, which may include different osmotic agents and buffers, as well as variations in
electrolytes. The different osmotic agents include glucose, glucose polymers (icodextrin),
amino acids, and polypeptides. Glucose is an inexpensive osmotic agent, however, both
glucose and its degradation products (GDP) can induce injury to the peritoneal
membrane through both vascular proliferation and induction of fibrosis. Icodextrin
contains less GDP than standard glucose-containing solutions while having the
advantage of preserved ultrafiltration with long dwells. Icodextrin has been shown to
improve ultrafiltration, better control fluid overload, preserve residual renal function, and
improve creatinine clearance when compared to standard glucose-containing PD
solutions. Amino acid-based PD solution contains no GDP, but may also act as a
potential protein source for malnourished PD patients.
The different buffering agents are lactate (only available in the United States), acetate,
and bicarbonate, with some solutions containing a combination of buffers (mainly lactate
and bicarbonate). The concentration of buffer can vary from 34 mEq/L to 40 mEq/L.
Citrate has been considered as an alternative, as it may also provide anti-coagulative
properties. However, to date, there are limited studies in animals, without any clear
advantages seen with its use.

For patients receiving acute PD, some modifications (such as potassium) in the dialysate
solution can be provided depending on the patient’s clinical status; alterations in
dialysate calcium or bicarbonate concentration are not recommended due to risk of
precipitation. For patients receiving chronic care, the electrolyte concentrations in
commercially available PD solutions can vary some, but not greatly, with the
concentration of calcium being altered most commonly. The typical electrolyte
concentration ranges for patients receiving chronic care are:
 Sodium, 130 mEq/L to 137 mEq/L (130-137 mmol/L) (132 mEq/L in North
America)
 Calcium, 10 mg/dL to 14 mg/dL (2.5-3.5 mmol/L)
 Magnesium, 0.5 mEq/L to 1.5 mEq/L (0.25-0.75 mmol/L)
 Potassium, 0 mEq/L to 2 mEq/L (0-2 mmol/L) (0 being most commonly used)
Most commercially utilized bicarbonate-based solutions are available with similar
concentrations of sodium, glucose, calcium, and magnesium as lactate-based solutions.
There is also no reported difference in the peritoneal transport characteristics of these
solutions, so there should be no difference in the serum levels of these electrolytes when
switching from bicarbonate-based to lactate-based solutions. Decreased reflexes from
hypermagnesemia should not occur, as standard PD solutions contain 0.5 mEq/L (0.25
mmol/L) of magnesium, which should not cause hypermagnesemia. Increased thirst
from hypernatremia should not occur, as the sodium concentration of solutions in North
America is 132 mEq/L (132 mmol/L), which is similar or slightly decreased from
standard solutions in Europe. Muscle cramping from hypokalemia is less likely to occur,
as acidosis is more likely to occur with the use of lactate-based solutions. Hypocalcemia
has not been seen at an increased rate with the use of lactate-based solutions compared
to bicarbonate-based solutions, while tetany has not been reported. One reported
change that has been seen with bicarbonate-based solution is improvement of acid-base
status in both adults and children.
PREP Pearls
 Bicarbonate-based peritoneal dialysate (PD) solutions feature a double chamber
bag, which is requisite to add both bicarbonate and calcium

 There are many benefits of bicarbonate-based solutions over lactate-based
solutions, but those that may be directly seen by providers are improvement in
acidosis, improvement in ultrafiltration, and avoidance of inflow pain
 There are some variations of electrolyte concentrations between different PD
solutions worldwide, but these variations are not that great for sodium and
potassium. The concentration of calcium in PD solution is one that is often
adjusted clinically
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the composition of the dialysate solutions for peritoneal dialysis and how to
alter standard solutions in different clinical situations
Suggested Readings
 Alam M, Krause MW. Peritoneal dialysis solutions. 2014. Accessed 7/15/2014 at:
www.uptodate.com/contents/peritoneal-dialysis-solutions
 Cho Y, Johnson DW, Craig JC, Strippoli GF, Badve SV, Wiggins KJ. Biocompatible
dialysis fluids for peritoneal dialysis. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2014;3:CD007554.
DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007554.pub2
 Diaz-Buxo JA. Bicarbonate solutions: update. Adv Perit Dial. 2005;21:115-119.
 García-López E, Lindholm B, Davies S. An update on peritoneal dialysis solutions.
Nat Rev Nephrol. 2012;8(4):224–233. DOI: 10.1038/nrneph.2012.13

You are caring for an 11-year-old boy who is now 6 months status post-living unrelated renal
transplant with a 3 mismatch donor kidney. The post-transplant course has been unremarkable, with
good renal function soon after transplant and stable serum creatinine generally about 0.6 mg/dL (53
µmol/L). He is maintained on a steroid-free immunosuppressive protocol with tacrolimus (current
trough levels between 6-8 mg/dL) and mycophenolate mofetil at 300 mg/m2/dose, given twice daily.
Over the last month, he has had vague upper respiratory symptoms, and at his last clinic visit, you
note his blood pressure (BP) was 140/90 mm Hg. At that time, you transitioned him from his calcium
channel blocker to an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor for better blood pressure control. A
week after this visit, he presents to the emergency department in respiratory distress. He is afebrile, a
BP of 130/80 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 36 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 89%. His physical
examination is significant for tachypnea with intercostal retractions, diffuse crackles, and expiratory
wheeze. His graft is nontender and he has no other notable physical examination findings. He is
admitted to the hospital, where his laboratory results reveal a serum potassium of 5.9 mEq/L (5.9
mmol/L), serum creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL (115 µmol/L), hemoglobin of 10 g/dL (100 g/L), and a white
blood cell count of 4,500/µL (4.5 x 109/L). The other laboratory findings are unremarkable.
Of the following, the MOST likely etiology for this patient’s pulmonary symptoms is
options: pleural effusion The answer is A The clinical history, and timing of presentation of this ‘s respiratory distress makes flash pulmonary edema the most likely etiology of his pulmonary symptoms. Flash pulmonary edema is a known complication in individuals with renal artery stenosis (RAS), which can be exacerbated by the initiation of an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi). Renal artery stenosis can occur any time after renal transplantation, with it more commonly occurring between 3 months and 2 years post-transplant. Risk factors for the development of post-transplant RAS include surgical complications related to the harvest and anastomosis, delayed graft function, cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, and donor atherosclerotic disease. Renal artery stenosis of any cause leads to renal hypoperfusion and a decrease in intraglomerular flow. To preserve renal blood flow and glomerular filtration, the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is activated, leading to increased salt and water retention, changes in vascular tone, and increased sympathetic nervous system activity. The resultant increase in effective circulating volume and direct systemic vasoconstriction causes systemic hypertension, as there is no opportunity for negative feedback with continued renal hypoperfusion seen with stenosis. In addition to these effects, angiotensin II helps maintain intraglomerular pressure and therefore the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by preferentially increasing efferent arteriolar resistance. As opposed to the circumstance in patients with 2 functioning kidneys, in patients with a solitary kidney, there is reduced ability to modulate sodium and water secretion, resulting in the increased proclivity of hypertension due to volume retention (ie, lack of pressure diuresis). This has been demonstrated in experimental studies comparing the 2-kidney 1-clip (unilateral RAS with a normal contralateral kidney) versus the 1-kidney 1-clip (unilateral RAS with no contralateral kidney). In the 2-kidney 1-clip model, the contralateral kidney can compensate by enhancing sodium and water excretion, which is not feasible in the 1-kidney 1-clip model. These autoregulatory responses are also disrupted and largely reversed with ACE inhibition and angiotensin II blockade. These agents cause a reduction in intraglomerular pressure by preferentially dilating the efferent arteriole and blocking angiotensin II production (ACEi) or action (angiotensin II receptor blocker; ARB). In addition, the effective circulating volume may be reduced and systemic blood pressure lowered, reducing renal blood flow further. With significant reductions in blood pressure, either with ACEi/ARB therapy or other antihypertensive agents, renal perfusion can be decreased to the point where functional renal mass is lost. This loss of functional renal tissue occurs because of cortical ischemia, interstitial inflammation, tubular atrophy, and irreversible fibrosis. Use of an ACEi or an ARB in individuals with RAS, either those with a solitary (native or transplanted) kidney or those with bilateral disease, can lead to several complications soon after starting therapy. One of the more commonly known adverse effects of these medications is a rise in serum creatinine, related to the reversible decline in the GFR described. A rise in plasma creatinine of 30% or more after starting ACEi or ARB therapy is suggestive of RAS. This impairment in renal function with angiotensin inhibition can also lead to hyperkalemia, as was seen in the patient in the vignette. Flash pulmonary edema (FPE) is another known complication of ACEi/ARB therapy in patients with either bilateral RAS or unilateral stenosis of a solitary kidney. While FPE is commonly associated with acute decompensated heart failure, FPE in this setting occurs because of amplification of the pulmonary RAAS, increased sympathetic nervous system activation, and reduction in nitric oxide production. Together, this results in enhanced vasoconstriction and endothelial dysfunction. Ultimately, left ventricular end diastolic pressure increase, exacerbating the neurohumoral activation and causing pulmonary capillary stress failure. Patients present in respiratory distress with cough, dyspnea and tachypnea, with or without chest pain. An examination may reveal hypertension, a heart murmur, S3, rales, hepatomegaly, or peripheral edema. A chest radiograph would show pulmonary edema. Other findings associated with RAS include resistant hypertension and an acute rise in blood pressure. In the patient described in the vignette, he had controlled blood pressure until recently, which also coincided with upper respiratory symptoms. It is possible that CMV infection, a known cause of RAS, or another infectious agent could have led to pneumonia; however, the lack of a fever does not support this diagnosis. Pneumothorax, pulmonary embolism, and pleural effusion are other causes of respiratory distress; however, the clinical presentation in this vignette that includes acute kidney injury and hyperkalemia, makes FPE related to ACEi/ARB initiation the most likely etiology. American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)  Know the issues related to renovascular disease in a patient with a solitary kidney Suggested Readings  Rimoldi SF, Yuzefpolskaya M, Allemann Y, Messerli F. Flash pulmonary edema. Prog Cardiovasc Dis. 2009;52(3):249-259. DOI: 10.1016/j.pcad.2009.10.002

 You are seeing a previously healthy 4-year-old boy who was admitted to the intensive care
unit 3 days ago with high fevers, chills, vomiting, oliguria, and hypotension. Initial laboratory
test results revealed a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 25 mg/dL (8.9 mmol/L) and a serum
creatinine of 0.4 mg/dL (35 µmol/L). Over the past 3 days, he has required multiple fluid
boluses and a vasopressor to maintain his blood pressure. He has remained oliguric. He has
developed a 20% fluid overload and is on mechanical ventilation. Laboratory tests today show
a BUN of 102 mg/dL (36.4 mmol/L), serum creatinine of 4.8 mg/dL (424 µmol/L), and serum
potassium of 7 mEq/L (7 mmol/L). An initial blood culture is positive for Escherichia coli.
 Of the following, the BEST next step in the management to optimize small solute clearance is
to initiate

options: peritoneal dialysis (PD) Answer B The patient in this vignette has the typical clinical manifestations of sepsis-induced acute kidney injury (AKI). Based on the increase in serum creatinine to greater than 3 times the baseline value, as well as the persistent oliguria, he has AKI stage 3 based on Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) staging. He has also developed azotemia, hyperkalemia, and a 20% fluid overload. He remains critically ill, on mechanical ventilation, with hemodynamic instability, requiring vasopressor therapy for blood pressure maintenance. He needs urgent renal replacement therapy for fluid removal, as well as clearance of potassium and nitrogenous wastes, in a manner that will not compromise hemodynamic stability. Mere fluid restriction will not be sufficient. In an ideal situation, the preferred modality of therapy is continuous veno-venous hemodiafiltration (CVVHDF). In general, the indications for dialysis in pediatric AKI include the following:  Symptomatic uremia  Hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, or acidosis unresponsive to nondialytic medical management  Fluid overload  Oliguria requiring fluid restriction that limits nutritional and other supportive care In critically ill children, the epidemiology of AKI has changed from primary renal diseases to one characterized by a consequence of other systemic or multi-organ disease. Fluid overload and oliguria requiring fluid restriction have emerged as the most common reasons to initiate renal replacement therapy in the intensive care unit (ICU). The Prospective Pediatric Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy Registry Group, via the analysis of its 340 patient cohort, showed that when fluid overload was dichotomized to greater than 20% and less than 20%, patients with greater than 20% fluid overload at continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) initiation had an adjusted mortality odds ratio of 8.5 (95% confidence interval, 2.8-25.7). These findings have now been confirmed in adults with AKI and fluid overload. Furthermore, outcomes were superior when CRRT was initiated earlier in the ICU course. Thus, the available data, although largely observational, indicates that outcomes are improved if CRRT is initiated earlier in the clinical course and at a lesser degree of fluid overload. The child in this vignette, with a documented 20% fluid overload, ongoing oliguria, and ongoing anticipated need for supportive critical care (including nutrition, antibiotics, vasopressors, and blood products) is ideally suited to receive CRRT. Over the past 2 decades, CRRT has become the preferred modality for the management of the critically ill, hemodynamically unstable child with AKI and fluid overload. This is in part due to advances in CRRT technology, allowing for more precise and reliable treatment delivery with greater ease of operation. Clinical experience has demonstrated several advantages of CRRT over more traditional dialytic modalities in critically ill patients. Removal of fluid and solutes occurs gradually, but continuously during CRRT. Therefore, hemodynamically unstable patients who may not tolerate large volume and solute concentration changes that characterize standard hemodialysis can be safely managed with CRRT. While peritoneal dialysis can also provide gradual clearance of solutes and fluid, CRRT has the advantage of independently controlling the degree of fluid removal and solute clearance. Furthermore, certain modalities of CRRT can provide solute clearance that exceed the efficiency of standard peritoneal dialysis treatments. The nomenclature of CRRT is based on the ensuing primary method of solute clearance. Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) provides primarily fluid removal, with convective solute clearance afforded by the high ultrafiltration rates. In continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), the majority of solute clearance is diffusive, provided by the countercurrent infusion of dialysate through the hemofilter. In continuous veno-venous hemodiafiltration (CVVHDF), both diffusive and convective clearance of solutes is achieved. The choice of CRRT modality used is often based on institutional standards and familiarity, the availability of appropriate replacement and dialysis solutions, and the primary goal of therapy. CVVH is often employed when the primary goal is fluid removal. CVVHDF is the preferred modality in patients requiring improved small solute clearance in addition to fluid removal, such as those with azotemia or hyperkalemia (as is the case in this vignette). It should be noted that middle molecule (eg, β-2 microglobulin) clearance is superior with CVVH versus CVVHDF. Moreover, it should be acknowledged that solute clearance, especially using postdilution replacement fluids, with CVVH alone would also likely be of nearly equal efficacy for the child in this vignette, if institutional preference and limitations in availability of dialysate fluid steer the clinician in that direction. Intermittent hemodialysis (IHD) provides rapid ultrafiltration and solute removal, and is often the modality of choice for the treatment of ingestions, drug toxicity, severe fluid overload, and severe hyperkalemia. A 4-hour IHD session provides solute and fluid clearance comparable to 24 hours of CRRT. IHD can be performed outside of critical care units and provides a large window of dialysis-free time for procedures and imaging, which can be complicated in patients on CRRT. In addition, in contrast to CRRT, there is reliable information on drug clearance in IHD. However, the major disadvantage of IHD is hemodynamic instability and hypotension, which commonly occur in critically ill children. This often leads to early termination of treatment and limited ability to achieve the fluid and solute removal goals. In addition, fluid restriction is usually required during the 20 hours of dialysis- free time, which can compromise ongoing clinical care and nutrition. Hence, IHD is not best suited for the child in this vignette. Peritoneal dialysis (PD) has historically been the most widely employed dialytic modality in children with AKI, and remains widely used in facilities where IHD and CRRT are not available. Just like CRRT, PD provides gentle continuous removal of fluid and solutes. However, CRRT technology now allows for a greater degree of, and better precision in, daily clearance rates of fluid and solutes in comparison to PD. Ultrafiltration and solute clearance occur slowly with PD, therefore this modality is not optimal in patients with severe volume overload or hyperkalemia (as is the case in this vignette). Furthermore, patients on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory compromise may not tolerate large volumes of dialysate in the abdomen. Finally, PD should be approached with caution in patients with suspected intra-abdominal pathology.  You are evaluating a 3-month-old African American infant with nephrocalcinosis. He was born
preterm at 27 weeks gestational age, received ventilator therapy for 4 weeks, and also
received surfactant therapy for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. He also had transient
hypertension and was treated with a calcium channel blocker for about 4 weeks.
 Of the following, the MOST important predisposing factor for the development of
nephrocalcinosis in this infant is

options: neonatal respiratory distress syndrome Answer C Nephrocalcinosis (NC) in children may occur at any age, but is more prevalent in the first few years after birth. The main reason for this phenomenon is that NC is often caused by inborn errors of metabolism or tubular abnormalities that exist at birth. A rare but treatable cause of NC is primary hyperoxaluria. Several other main etiologies of NC are shown in the Table. The pathogenesis of NC, regardless of the cause, involves 2 main mechanisms. The initial event is the formation of crystals in the renal tubule. This provides a nidus for retention for aggregation of the crystal. It should be noted that adherence of calcium to the tubular epithelium requires intact, undamaged epithelium. Interestingly, immature or proliferating epithelium (as seen more commonly in newborns and infants) is uniquely vulnerable to crystal formation. Any factor (presence of stone inhibitors) that protects against crystal formation and growth will counteract the development of NC. The infant in the vignette has a typical history for the development of NC. The most important factor contributing to the development of NC in this infant is immaturity of the renal tubules, which provides a nidus for calcium crystallization. A history of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) or (hyaline membrane disease) is not uncommon in infants who develop NC, usually due to furosemide (loop diuretic) use, which promotes hypercalciuria and NC. While a history of furosemide use is not mentioned in the vignette, it is a major risk factor for NC. African American children are less likely to develop NC than white children; epidemiological data in children of other races are lacking. Since calcium channel blockers enhance cellular uptake of calcium, their use would tend to decrease, not increase the risk for NC. Worldwide, the incidence of NC is similar in males and females. A history of NRDS itself does not increase the likelihood of developing NC. Early studies suggested a very guarded prognosis for children with NC. Pope et al studied 13 infants who developed NC from loop diuretic use. Over the follow-up period of up to 10 months, NC resolved in 6 patients, but persisted in 7. The mean time to resolution was 5.2 months following discontinuation of the diuretic. Ezzedeen et al followed 17 infants with NC due to diuretic therapy. They found that despite resolution of imaging evidence of NC in the majority of patients, renal function remained compromised in some. Downing et al assessed renal function in 27 preterm infants, including 10 who received furosemide and developed NC. Compared to infants that did not receive furosemide or who received furosemide but did not develop NC, those with NC had significantly lower renal function, higher urinary calcium/creatinine ratios and fractional excretion of sodium, lower tubular reabsorption of phosphate, and impaired bicarbonate reabsorption. More recent studies suggest that if the cause can be addressed, spontaneous resolution occurs in the majority of preterm infants. One prospective study showed that NC persists in 35% of patients at 15 months and 15% of patients at 30 months, with 10% to 25% showing persistent radiological findings 7.5 years later. The renal function was similar in those with or without radiologic evidence of persistent lesions. Other complications or associated symptoms may develop with NC, including hematuria, urinary tract infection, and urolithiasis. Management initially involves identifying clues to the etiology. Eliminating the offending agent (eg, furosemide) or the treatment of underlying renal disorder (eg, renal tubular acidosis) is essential to reducing the long term morbidity of NC. Initial testing includes obtaining a baseline urine calcium-to- creatinine ratio, serum chemistry, including calcium, creatinine, and phosphate levels, and if the diagnosis is unclear, serum parathyroid hormone and vitamin D levels. Once diagnosed and the cause identified, management of NC involves meticulous re-assessment of renal involvement. This requires serial ultrasonography, intermittent measurement of renal function, and intermittent surveillance of urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio. stem:
You are asked to evaluate a 2-year-old boy with persistent proteinuria. He has previously been seen
by an ophthalmologist for poor vision of unknown cause. The parents also report that he has not
reached his cognitive milestones. On physical examination, the boy has pinpoint pupils that do not
seem to respond to light stimuli, slightly reduced muscle tone, moderate lower leg edema, and a blood
pressure of 122/78 mm Hg. Urinalysis reveals 4+ protein without blood. His serum creatinine is 1.4
mg/dL (124 µmol/L). You perform a renal biopsy, which reveals increased mesangial matrix,
segmental glomerulosclerosis, diffuse foot process effacement (electron microscopy), and moderate
tubulointerstitial (inflammation, tubular atrophy, fibrosis) changes.
Of the following, the factor MOST likely to be responsible for this patient’s renal disease is
options: type IV collagen Answer: B The boy in the vignette has poor vision, small pupils poorly responsive to light, cognitive developmental delay, hypotonia, and evidence of nephrotic syndrome and reduced renal function. The renal biopsy is consistent with abnormalities of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) (diffuse foot process effacement), increased mesangial matrix, segmental sclerosis, and moderate tubulointerstitial disease. This constellation of findings is consistent with Pierson syndrome. Pierson syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, and is caused by mutations in the LAMB2 gene that encodes for the laminin β2 protein. Since laminin β2 is required for the formation of normal basement membranes, patients with Pierson syndrome feature nephrotic syndrome (may be congenital or appear later in childhood) and ocular complications (eg, abnormal lens, retinal, and cornea). Some affected individuals may also develop microcoria and hypotonia, as was evident in this child. The symptomatology and age of onset of the various symptoms in Pierson syndrome vary. While the patient described in the vignette has nephrotic syndrome that developed at 2 years of age, the renal disease onset and severity varies in affected children. In a case report by VanDeVoorde et al, the affected patient presented at birth and renal biopsy revealed diffuse mesangial sclerosis. In general, glomerular diseases comprise a vast array of disorders characterized by specific derangements of glomerular structures. The capillary wall is the unit where filtration occurs, and itself is composed of endothelial cells and the GBM. The GBM consists of collagen, laminin, polyanionic proteoglycans, fibronectin, and other glycoproteins, podocytes/foot processes, and mesangial cells. The GBM is subdivided into 3 parts: lamina densa, lamina rara interna, and lamina rara externa. All 3 parts of the basement membrane are comprised of 2 main elements: 1. Basal lamina: An extracellular matrix that is comprised of type IV collagen, laminin, nidogen, and heparan sulfate proteoglycans. The basal lamina is an essential part of the glomerular filtration barrier. It provides a barrier between the epithelial cells (podocytes) and the underlying connective tissue. Pathology develops if this barrier is interrupted. The basal lamina of the visceral epithelium fuses with the glomerular capillaries, forming a filtration membrane. 2. Reticular lamina: Made of reticular tissue, collagen fibers, and matrix. It provides support for the basal lamina. Laminin and type IV collagen are the major components of the basal lamina, with type IV collagen being most abundant. These chains interject to form a mesh-like polymer. Laminin has binding sites for nidogen (or entactin), proteoglycans, α-dystroglycan, and integrins. The role of the GBM components in renal disease is profound. Indeed, different isoforms of these molecules are produced and each is found in certain tissues. Alport syndrome is the most widely known renal disease involving disruption of the basal lamina. Patients with Alport syndrome feature progressive nephritis and hearing loss. The prevalence of Alport syndrome is estimated at 1 out of 5,000, although this may vary according to locale. The histology includes thickening of the GBM with splitting and fragmentation of the lamina densa, forming the classic “basket weave” pattern. The genetics reveal an abnormality in type IV collagen of the basal lamina. Other diseases characterized by abnormalities in the components of the GBM are listed in the Table. Proteoglycans (eg, heparan sulfate) are essential components in the GBM. They play a vital role the proper organization and function of the GBM, and help maintain the selective permeability of the GBM. Heparan sulfate proteoglycans bind chemokines and help recruit leukocytes to the extracellular matrix, thereby contributing to inflammation. However, there is no evidence that proteoglycans are involved in the pathogenesis of Pierson syndrome. Nidogen (also termed entactin) is another important GBM component that binds laminin and type IV collagen. Studies suggest its potential involvement in disorders of renal development (eg, renal agenesis), but not in glomerular disease. As mentioned, abnormalities in type IV collagen cause Alport syndrome and benign familial hematuria, each with characteristic renal and extrarenal manifestations. Patients with Alport syndrome or benign familial hematuria have features distinct from patients with Pierson syndrome. Finally, fibronectin has been implicated in fibronectin glomerulopathy, a disease mainly observed in adults and featured by nephrotic syndrome and glomerular deposits with fibril formation, but without extrarenal manifestations.
